ygData.subject: Porting to Cantera: an offer of help
ygData.msgSnippet: In the interest of building a base of useful Cantera-based applications, I will make the following offer: If you have a Fortran or C++ application that could

Subject: Porting to Cantera: an offer of help
Message-ID: <9ur2m5+mklg@...>
User-Agent: eGroups-EW/0.82
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=ISO-8859-1
Content-Length: 2020

From: "dggoodwin" <dgoodwin@...>
X-Yahoo-Group-Post: member; u=44728387
X-Yahoo-Profile: dggoodwin


In the interest of building a base of useful Cantera-based 
applications, I will make the following offer:

If you have a Fortran or C++ application that could use Cantera AND 
(here's the catch) that you are willing to make broadly available in 
some form to the Cantera user community, I will provide substantial 
assistance in porting it to Cantera. Eligible programs include 
anything of reasonably general interest, from flame or reactor 
numerical models to pre- or post-processors, etc.

Benefits:
1) Your program may run substantially faster, particularly if it does 
kinetics calculations.
2) Your application will be based on open-source libraries.
3) You receive the recognition associated with providing useful 
software tools to the user community.
4) You will further the goal of open-source software tools for 
reacting flow simulation and analysis.

Ground rules:

1) the code must be in the public domain, or you must hold copyright 
to the files you submit, or you must certify that contributing it 
does not violate any license terms of any third-party code your 
application uses.

2) The program cannot contain any source code that is part of Chemkin 
(any version - I,II, or III), or any other commercial software 
library. It is fine if it contains calls to subroutines in such 
libraries, since these calls will be replaced by calls to equivalent 
Cantera procedures in the porting process.

3) You agree that a tar or zip archive of your program can be posted 
on a web site. It will not be part of the Cantera distribution, but 
will be available for download from a page devoted to third-party 
Cantera-based applications. (The idea is something like NetLib.)

4) Your code will retain your copyright, you will decide what files 
go in the posted archive, and it will be subject to the license terms 
you specify (i.e., the GNU Public License or something else).


If you are possibly interested in doing this, please contact me off-
line at dgoodwin@.... First come, first served.
